acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 1 from 48 hours EC50=585.52microg/L of the crustacea (Daphnia magna) (CICAD60, 2004).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "liquid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_vapor.rationale: Based on the LC50 value of 16.5mg/L (3,526ppm), calculated from the testing data of rat LC50 (7 hour inhalation of vapour)  of 13.5mg/L (EHC 167, 1995), was lower than 90% of the saturated vapor concentration (16,000 ppm) under a saturated vapour pressure of 1.6 kPa (25degC) (HSDB, 2005), the substance was considered as "vapour containing substantially no mist" and was classified based on standard values expressed in ppm.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the testing data of rat LD50 (oral route) of 2,914mg/kg (MOE Risk Assessment Vol. 3, 2004).

aspiration_hazard.hazard_statement: May be harmful if swallowed and enters airways
aspiration_hazard.rationale: Based on the description in ICSC (J) (2003): "May cause aspiration and chemical pneumonia if swallowed".

carcinogenicity.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as Category A3 by ACGIH (2001).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Very toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Although acute toxicity is Category 1 and bio-accumulation is low (BCF=39.6(Existing Chemical Safety Inspections Data, )), since there was no rapidly degrading (the decomposition by BOD: 5%(Existing Chemical Safety Inspections Data)), it was classified into Category 1.

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Classified into Class 3 (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods, UN#1134 )

explosives.rationale: Containing no atom groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases
flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: The flashing point is 27degC (ICSC, 2003) (closed cup flash test), which is classified into Category 3, or Class 3 and Container III (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods, UN#1134)

flammable_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on negative data on heritable mutagenicity tests (dominant lethal tests), positive data on somatic cell mutagenicity tests in vivo (micronucleus tests) and the absence of data on germ cell mutagenicity and genotoxicity tests in vivo, described in CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.82 (2005).

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Organic compounds containing chlorine (but not oxygen and fluorine), with the chlorine bound to carbon and hydrogen (but not to other elements)

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Not pyrophoric when in contact with air at ordinary temperatures: the flashing point is 590degC (ICSC, 2003)

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

reproductive_toxicity.rationale: Based on the report that no reproductive or developmental toxicity was observed at dosing levels not toxic to parent animals, described in CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.82 (2005).

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Containing no atom groups with explosive or self-reactive properties

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the evidence of "moderate irritation" from rabbit and guinea pig eye irritation tests (ACGIH 7th, 2001) and human reports (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.82, 2005).

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on the evidence of "moderate irritation" from rabbit skin irritation tests (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.82, 2005) and human reports (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.82, 2005).

skin_sensitizer.rationale: Insufficient data available, although the substance was reported negative in guinea pig maximization tests (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.82, 2005).

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Containing no metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At)

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.classification:
Category 1 (central nervous system, peripheral nervous system, blood system),
Category 2 (liver, kidney, adrenal gland)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement:
Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (central nervous system, peripheral nervous system, blood system)
May cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (liver, kidney, adrenal gland)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence of "numbness, cyanosis (due to respiratory center depression), hyperesthesia, muscular spasm" (ATSDR, 1990) and the evidence of "necrosis of hepatocytes, degeneration of renal cortical tubules, vacuolation of adrenal zona reticularis cells, neutropenia" (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.82, 2005) from animal studies. The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value range for Category 2 (except for the effects on the blood systems, which corresponded to Category 1).

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement:
Causes damage to organs (systemic toxicity)
May cause drowsiness or dizziness (narcotic effects)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence of "debility, nausea and lethargy observed as general symptoms of acute toxicity after occupational exposure" (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No. 82, 2005).
